history.content:
Many hours. I would spend a minimum of 10-25 averaging 15+ hours per CS189 assignment. CS170 between 8 and 14 hours per assignment. Note CS189 assignments were every 2 weeks while CS170 assignments were weekly. I am also a B+/A- student.

Recommended? Depends on what you've taken. CS189 has a mix of sizable programming assignments and linear-algebra heavy problem sets. CS162 and Math 110, while not directly relevant nor required, are good classes to have taken for programming and mathematical maturity. (CS162 is a high bar; another project-based upper division CS course would be comparable). Again, not required, but sufficient maturity is necessary to being successful in CS189 either having already earned it or by earning it in the course through lots of (smart) effort and hours. 170 is similar (no programming tho), but with algorithmic type thinking. If you did well in the proof portions of CS70 (think B+ or better), then you are sufficiently ready for CS170. Doing both together is hard as both classes require time to complete the assignments and absorb the concepts -- both are very much classes whose content you sit and think on, not just dash off a problem set and forget about until the exam.

TLDR; It's possible to take both if a) experienced, b) willing to risk doing less than stellar in both, and c) prepared to not do much (anything) else during the semester. Pick 2.

Recommended? Depends on what you've taken. CS189 has a mix of sizable programming assignments and linear-algebra heavy problem sets. TLDR; It's possible to take both if a) experienced, b) willing to risk doing less than stellar in both, and c) prepared to not do much (anything) else during the semester. Pick 2.

children.subject: Doable if you're a math god (for CS 189) or clever/hardworking (for CS 170). Source: took both at the same time and discovered that I'm none of these things.

history.content: How many hours would this take? Recommended for a B+/A- student?
history.subject: CS189 + CS170 concurrently
